head.title: Polyvinylalcohol (PVA)-Assisted Exfoliation of ReS2 Nanosheets and the Use of ReS2–PVA Composites for Transparent Memristive Photosynapse Devices | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Polyvinylalcohol (PVA)-Assisted Exfoliation of ReS2 Nanosheets and the Use of ReS2–PVA Composites for Transparent Memristive Photosynapse Devices

Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have attracted significant attention for their outstanding optoelectrical properties. Unlike most TMDs with layer-dependent photoresponsivity, rhenium disulfide (ReS2) shows excellent thickness-independent photoresponsivity. Herein, we show a surfactant-free polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)-assisted exfoliation method for 2D-TMDs in aqueous solution and a transparent photosensitive memristor synapse device based on ReS2 nanosheets composited with PVA. ReS2 nanosheets are obtained via PVA-assisted exfoliation. After exfoliation, the ReS2–PVA dispersion solution is spin-coated on a substrate and dried to form a nanocomposite film without additional processing. Transparent memristors are then fabricated on plastic or glass substrates to demonstrate the applicability of the ReS2–PVA film. The devices show “write once, read many” memory behavior with a high ON/OFF current ratio (1.0 × 104 at 0.5 V) during electrical operation. In the high resistive state, synaptic functions with long-term memory behavior are successfully mimicked by applying photonic stimuli to the transparent ReS2–PVA memristors. The excitatory postsynaptic current stimulated by the photosignal is gradually reduced by electric stimuli. The proposed PVA-assisted exfoliation method is cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and applicable to various TMD nanomaterials. Furthermore, the ReS2–PVA nanocomposite film obtained via a simple solution-based process demonstrates excellent photosynaptic behavior.

div.p:
Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have attracted significant attention for their outstanding optoelectrical properties. Unlike most TMDs with layer-dependent photoresponsivity, rhenium disulfide (ReS
2
) shows excellent thickness-independent photoresponsivity. Herein, we show a surfactant-free polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)-assisted exfoliation method for 2D-TMDs in aqueous solution and a transparent photosensitive memristor synapse device based on ReS
2
nanosheets composited with PVA. ReS
2
nanosheets are obtained via PVA-assisted exfoliation. After exfoliation, the ReS
2
–PVA dispersion solution is spin-coated on a substrate and dried to form a nanocomposite film without additional processing. Transparent memristors are then fabricated on plastic or glass substrates to demonstrate the applicability of the ReS
2
–PVA film. The devices show “write once, read many” memory behavior with a high ON/OFF current ratio (1.0 × 10
4
at 0.5 V) during electrical operation. In the high resistive state, synaptic functions with long-term memory behavior are successfully mimicked by applying photonic stimuli to the transparent ReS
2
–PVA memristors. The excitatory postsynaptic current stimulated by the photosignal is gradually reduced by electric stimuli. The proposed PVA-assisted exfoliation method is cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and applicable to various TMD nanomaterials. Furthermore, the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film obtained via a simple solution-based process demonstrates excellent photosynaptic behavior.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.p: This article was initially published with an incorrect copyright statement and was corrected on or around May 5, 2021.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are of interest because of their broad applicability in switching devices, batteries, catalysts, and sensors, as well as in memory devices.
(1−4)
Among their applications, new functional devices showing artificial synaptic functions that utilize TMDs as active layers are very promising. Artificial intelligence systems based on synaptic devices and neuromorphic computing have shown great potential in enabling a myriad of innovative and intelligent applications, including perception, recognition, learning, and decision making.
(5−7)
Recently, synaptic devices utilizing new functional materials that use extremely complicated circuits are attracting much interest, aside from approaches that mimic the human brain.
(8,9)

With regard to implementing TMD-based synaptic devices, tape-exfoliated TMD nanoflakes are unsuitable for large-area device fabrication,
(10)
and the growth of 2D TMD films on large substrates requires complex high-vacuum and high-temperature processes.
(11−13)
TMD nanosheets can also be obtained via liquid-phase exfoliation (LPE), including lithium cation (Li
+
) intercalation
(14)
and both chemical and nonchemical methods.
(15,16)
Among these, nonchemical LPE is the simplest and most effective method for the mass production of high-quality few-layer TMD nanosheets. Li
+
intercalation converts the MoS
2
of the semiconducting 2H phase into the metallic 1 T phase. Chemical exfoliation typically uses environmentally harmful and toxic organic solvents, such as pyrrolidone.
(16,17)
For nonchemical LPE that uses shear forces in solutions, surfactants are necessary to obtain high yields of hydrophobic TMD nanosheets. Occasionally, the exfoliation yield can be enhanced by adding cations, such as Na
+
.
(14,18)
However, the surfactant and cationic additives must be removed from the nanosheets before device fabrication.

When most 2D TMD materials are scaled down from bulk to a monolayer, their band gaps undergo transition from indirect to direct owing to the quantum confinement effect. Therefore, previous studies on optoelectronic devices have focused on monolayers. Although monolayers have superior optical properties, their low absorbance limits the performance of the resulting devices. Bulk and monolayer rhenium disulfide (ReS
2
) with distorted 1 T phase structures have similar electrical, optical, and vibrational properties owing to their weak interlayer coupling. In particular, both monolayer and multilayer ReS
2
have direct band gaps because of this weak interlayer coupling, unlike other TMDs, such as MoS
2
, MoSe
2
, WS
2
, and WSe
2
,
(19−23)
Moreover, ReS
2
stacks of greater thickness absorb more light.
(24)
Therefore, both forms of ReS
2
are useful for photodetectors and phototransistors.

In this work, we developed a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)-assisted exfoliation method for 2D TMDs, including ReS
2
, in a surfactant-free aqueous solution for the first time. PVA is a nontoxic, inexpensive, and water-soluble polymer, and it can be used as a matrix polymer for the formation of 2D nanosheet-embedded films. This PVA-assisted exfoliation method produced highly concentrated aqueous dispersions of 2D nanosheets with no agents requiring removal before the formation of a ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film on a substrate. The PVA adsorbed onto the surface and entered between the layers of ReS
2
in the ReS
2
–PVA solution, as depicted in
Figure
1
b. We presume that PVA molecules behaved as a surfactant and stabilizer of exfoliated nanosheets simultaneously. The yield can increase with sonication time.
Figure
1
compares the procedure for film formation using the PVA-assisted exfoliation method with that of conventional LPE. As shown, the conventional process includes the washing and dissolution processes prior to film formation. On the contrary, our method yielded a nanocomposite film by spin-coating the ReS
2
–PVA dispersion directly onto the substrate.

div.p:
Figure 1. Fabrication of ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite films using (a) conventional LPE and (b) PVA-assisted exfoliation methods.

div.div:
Using the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film, we fabricated a simply structured memristor device with a transparent top electrode, an Al
2
O
3
buffer layer, a ReS
2
–PVA active layer, and a transparent bottom electrode. Under an applied electric field, the memristor showed “write once, read many” (WORM) memory behavior with a high ON/OFF current ratio of 1.0 × 10
4
at 0.5 V. In the low-current regime, the increase in current with respect to the electric field is attributable to the space charge-limited conduction (SCLC) process.

In the high resistive state (HRS) regime, for the first time, the synaptic plasticity of the transparent ReS
2
–PVA memristor was modulated by applying photonic stimuli. Synaptic plasticity depends on repetitive experiences; the device successfully mimicked excitatory synaptic behavior such as excitatory postsynaptic current (EPSC), paired pulse facilitation (PPF), long-term potentiation (LTP), and long-term memory (LTM) by modulating the pulse width (PW) and pulse number (PN) of 365 nm ultraviolet (UV) light. Inhibitory synaptic behavior such as long-term depression (LTD) was also emulated using electrical stimuli.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
Exfoliation of ReS
2
with PVA and no Surfactant in Aqueous Solution
div.div:
ReS
2
(Alfa Aesar), MoS
2
(Sigma-Aldrich), MoSe
2
(Alfa Aesar), WS
2
(Alfa Aesar), and WSe
2
(Alfa Aesar) powders were used as raw materials. PVA (
M
W
≈ 166,000, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as the exfoliation agent, and it formed the matrix of the nanocomposite films. All source materials were used without further purification. For the exfoliation of ReS
2
, only PVA was added to deionized(DI) water mixed with ethyl alcohol (EtOH). The concentration of PVA was varied from 0 to 5 wt % to investigate its effect on the ReS
2
exfoliation yield. The initial concentration of the ReS
2
powder was 10 mg mL
–1
. After sonication using a bath sonicator (Daihan WUC-D06H, 665 W, 40 kHz), the dispersion solutions were centrifuged at 1500 rpm for 15 min to remove sediments, as well as large thick nanosheets.

After removing the sediments, the absorbances of the ReS
2
dispersions were measured using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (LAMBDA 750; Perkin-Elmer). To avoid scattering problems, the dispersions were diluted with DI water. The concentrations of the dispersions were calculated using the Beer–Lambert law (
A
= α
Cl
, where
C
is the concentration,
l
is the length of the light path, and α is the predetermined absorption coefficient, as listed in
Table S1
). Raman spectroscopy (HORIBA JOBIN YVON Raman system) of ReS
2
in the dispersions was performed with a laser excitation wavelength of 514 nm.

After removing the sediments, each PVA solution containing exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets was spin-coated onto the substrate with no further treatment. The spin-coated films were dried at 100 °C in a drying oven to remove water and EtOH.

As a transparent conducting bottom electrode, 1.2 μm thick Ga-doped ZnO (GZO) was deposited on a glass substrate by RF magnetron sputtering at 200 °C. The 80 nm thick ReS
2
–PVA composite films were spin-coated on the GZO layers. Protective layers of 30 nm thick Al
2
O
3
were deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD) at 100 °C. Finally, transparent GZO, as the top electrode, was deposited through a shadow mask on the Al
2
O
3
at room temperature. The area of the top electrode was 1 mm
2
.

div.h3: Nanocomposite Thin Films and Device Characterization
div.div:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL, JEM-ARM200F) images of the ReS
2
nanosheets were acquired at an accelerating voltage of 300 kV. Nanoscale surface images of the ReS
2
nanosheets were obtained using atomic force microscopy (AFM; Park Systems, XE-100). The electrical properties of the memristors were measured using a parameter analyzer (Keithley 4200). The photosynaptic behavior of the memristors was examined using standard light-emitting diodes with wavelengths of 365, 400, and 455 nm as light sources.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We designed a new PVA-assisted exfoliation strategy to efficiently exfoliate 2D ReS
2
nanosheets in an aqueous solution with no toxic agents, cations, or additional surfactants. A ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film was then formed via a simple process. PVA is water-soluble, and it is easily washed out from the nanoflakes after the exfoliation process if pure nanoflakes are required. The ReS
2
nanosheets were exfoliated in an aqueous solution in the presence of PVA (0, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt %) macromolecules. EtOH was added to increase the exfoliation yield by decreasing the surface tension of the aqueous solution. After PVA-assisted exfoliation and centrifugation to remove un-exfoliated thick particles, the concentration of 2D nanosheets in each solution was determined using UV–visible absorption spectroscopy.

The concentration of ReS
2
in each solution was determined using the Beer–Lambert law and the suspension absorbance.
(18)
The absorption coefficient of ReS
2
used in the calculation (294 mL mg
–1
m
–1
) was obtained by calibrating the absorption intensities and known concentrations of the prepared samples (
Figure S1 and Table S1
).
Figure
2
a shows the absorption spectra of ReS
2
suspensions with different EtOH concentrations in aqueous solutions with 2 wt % PVA. As demonstrated, the highest ReS
2
concentration was acquired with 50 vol % EtOH. ReS
2
nanosheet concentrations of 1.35, 9.65, 13.8, and 8.59 mg mL
–1
were obtained at EtOH concentrations of 0, 25, 50, and 75 vol %, respectively. The concentration of 13.8 mg mL
–1
at 50 vol % EtOH was much higher than previously reported values using
N
-methylpyrrolidone (0.3 mg mL
–1
)
(25,26)
and EtOH (0.1 mg mL
–1
).
(27)
The observed increase in exfoliation yield as the EtOH concentration was increased from 0 to 50 vol % is ascribed to the addition of EtOH decreasing the surface tension, which inhibits PVA self-aggregation, resulting in an increase in the number of PVA molecules contributing to nanosheet exfoliation. Self-aggregation of PVA molecules occurs because both the hydrophobic parts and hydrophilic functional groups (−OH) are contained and the σ-bond between two carbon atoms rotates freely, as illustrated in
Figure S2
.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Absorption spectra of ReS
2
–PVA solutions as a function of ethyl alcohol (EtOH) concentration (25, 50, and 75 vol %). (b) Concentration of ReS
2
nanosheets as a function of PVA concentration (0, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt %). (c) Raman spectra of ReS
2
–PVA suspensions with 0, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt % PVA. (d) Re 4f photoelectron spectrum of exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets. (e) Cross-sectional TEM image of a ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite. (f) TGA data showing the relative compositions of PVA and ReS
2
in the ReS
2
–PVA dispersion solution.

div.div:
The surface tension of pure water is 72 mN m
–1
at 25 °C, and that of 50 vol % EtOH is lower than 30 mN m
–1
.
(28)
In our previous reports using surfactants,
(28,29)
the addition of EtOH reduced the surface tension of aqueous solutions and maintained smaller surfactant molecules, including monomers, that were more beneficial for the exfoliation of 2D nanosheets. The concentration of exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets was considerably lower when 75 vol % EtOH was used because PVA is less soluble in the EtOH-rich solution.
(30)

Figure
2
b shows the dependence of the ReS
2
nanosheet concentration on the PVA concentration; particularly, 2 wt % PVA resulted in the highest ReS
2
nanosheet concentration (13.8 mg mL
–1
). The significantly lower exfoliated nanosheet concentrations at 3 and 5 wt % (5.50 and 2.88 mg mL
–1
, respectively) must be due to severe PVA aggregation at concentrations exceeding the optimal level. Large PVA aggregates were observed in the 3–5 wt % aqueous solutions, which is probably due to limited PVA solubility.

Raman scattering analysis was also performed for 0, 1, 2, 3, and 5 wt % PVA dispersions to evaluate the presence of exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets.
(31,32)
The Raman spectra show ReS
2
peaks for all PVA solutions; the peak intensities of the samples exfoliated with 2 wt % PVA are stronger than those of the others, as shown in
Figure
2
c. No ReS
2
peaks are observed in the absence of PVA. The stability of a 2D nanosheet dispersion is important for ensuring reproducible processing. The ReS
2
suspensions with or without PVA are compared in
Figure S3a
; the solution with no PVA showed clear precipitation after 1 day. On the contrary, no precipitates were observed in suspensions with PVA, even after 6 months. MoS
2
, MoSe
2
, WS
2
, and WSe
2
were also exfoliated under the same conditions, namely, 50 vol % EtOH and 2 wt % PVA. As shown in
Figure S3b
, high 2D nanosheet concentrations were obtained by PVA-assisted exfoliation. Among the examined 2D materials, the ReS
2
suspension showed the highest concentration (13.8 mg mL
–1
) of 2D nanosheets. These results indicate that PVA-assisted exfoliation is highly effective for ReS
2
and that the 2D nanosheets remain stably dispersed in the aqueous PVA solution for several months.

To ensure that the ReS
2
nanosheets are not chemically degraded during exfoliation, the chemical bonding states of the exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Because the content of ReS
2
on the surface of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite films was very low, the ReS
2
specimen for surface-sensitive XPS analysis was prepared by removing PVA from the spin-coated ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite films at 450 °C under N
2
flow.
Figure
2
d shows the Re 4f XPS spectrum and deconvoluted peaks for the exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets. Neither Re
6+
(ReO
3
) nor Re metal peaks appear in the spectrum, which indicates that the chemical state of the ReS
2
nanosheets does not degrade during exfoliation or subsequent exposure to air.
Figure S4
shows the S 2p and Re 4f photoelectron spectra and the wide scan XPS spectrum of the sample. In the wide scan XPS spectrum, the intensities of the Re and S peaks were very low because the surface area filled with ReS
2
nanosheets was still small even after removing some of the PVA matrix. Because the sensitivity factor of S (1.67) is much lower than that of Re (11.08), the S 2p peak intensity was very low.

The ReS
2
nanosheets were subjected to scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and AFM to determine their lateral sizes and thicknesses, respectively, as shown in
Figures S5 and S6
. The samples were also prepared by removing PVA from the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite films.
Figure S5
shows SEM images of the ReS
2
nanosheets remaining on the glass substrate. For statistical analysis, the lateral sizes and thicknesses of 130 nanosheets were measured. The average lateral size of the ReS
2
nanosheets increased significantly from 10 to 500 nm as the PVA concentration was increased from 1 to 3 wt %, as shown in the SEM images and histograms. Bulk micrometer-scale crystallites and a small number of nanosheets were observed at 5 wt % PVA, which showed very low exfoliation efficiency, as presented in
Figure
2
b. The AFM height profiles showed that the ReS
2
nanosheets exfoliated using 2 and 5 wt % PVA were 1.4–16.6 and 10–60 nm thick, respectively, as shown in
Figure S6
. We used 2 wt % PVA condition for preparing ReS
2
nanosheets for devices. In contrast, the thickness of flakes exfoliated by
N
-methylpyrrolidone ranged from 20 to 560 nm.
(25,26)
The thickness is also affected by the sonication time and the centrifugation speed. The root mean square roughness values of the approximately 80 nm thick ReS
2
–PVA films with nanosheets exfoliated using 2 and 5 wt % PVA were 1.2 and 1.3 nm, respectively, as shown in
Figure S7
.

ReS
2
nanosheets in the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film prepared with 2 wt % PVA were characterized by TEM. The cross-sectional TEM images in
Figure
2
e show that the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film is uniform (low resolution, top), with ReS
2
nanosheets embedded in the PVA matrix (high resolution, bottom). HRTEM images of 2- and 5-layer ReS
2
nanosheets embedded in the PVA film as well as a 15-layer nanosheet given in
Figure S8
showed that the good crystallinity was maintained. To estimate the relative contents of ReS
2
and PVA in the film, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on the ReS
2
–PVA dispersion solution used in the film coating. As shown in
Figure S9
, a weight loss of almost 98% occurred before the temperature reached 110 °C, owing to solvent evaporation. As plotted in
Figure
2
f, which shows the normalized weight change in the temperature range of 200–400 °C, PVA gradually decomposed above 200 °C, and the remaining weight above 350 °C must be attributed to ReS
2
nanosheets. These results imply that the weight percentages of ReS
2
and PVA in the film were 43 and 57%, respectively.

To investigate whether the exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets composited with PVA can be used as electrical memory devices, ReS
2
–PVA memristors with simple structures were fabricated on transparent glass and flexible polymer substrates. The aqueous 2D nanosheet–polymer dispersion is compatible with polymer substrates. The device configuration is GZO/Al
2
O
3
/ReS
2
–PVA/GZO/transparent substrate, as shown in
Figure
3
a; photographic images of the transparent devices are presented in the insets of
Figure
3
b,c. The flexible transparent memory device was fabricated on a large-area (10 × 10 cm) colorless polyimide substrate. The ReS
2
–PVA film was formed by spin-coating the ReS
2
–PVA suspension, followed by drying to remove water and EtOH. A 30 nm thick Al
2
O
3
protective layer was deposited by ALD on the ReS
2
–PVA film; this layer acted as a barrier to eliminate unexpected early electrical breakdown and high off-current level that might be caused by the high surface roughness of the bottom GZO electrode (Supplementary Information,
Figure S10
) and the presence of large ReS
2
particles.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Schematic of the transparent device structure with the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite. (b)
I–V
characteristics of the transparent memristor with the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite (current compliance level: 1.0 mA). The inset of panel (b) shows a photographic image of the transparent device. (c)
I–V
characteristics of the flexible transparent memristor with the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite deposited on a colorless polyimide substrate. The inset of panel (c) shows a photographic image of the flexible transparent ReS
2
–PVA-based memristor. (d) Current as a function of retention time for the memristor. ln(
I
)–ln(
V
) curves of (e) OFF state and (f) ON state for the memristor. The inset of
Figure
2
e shows the ln(
I
)–
V
1/2
curve at voltages from 0 to 0.1 V.

div.div:
The devices with no Al
2
O
3
layer showed nonuniform current–voltage (
I–V
) characteristics even on the same substrate, as shown in
Figure S11a
. To evaluate device uniformity, the electrical characteristics of 10 devices fabricated on the same substrate were examined.
Figure S11b
shows that inclusion of the Al
2
O
3
layer leads to more uniform electrical characteristics. Schematic diagrams of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite films with and without the Al
2
O
3
layer are shown in
Figure S12
to illustrate how the Al
2
O
3
layer improved the uniformity of I–V characteristics of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film. In the devices fabricated even after a high-speed centrifugation process of the dispersion solution, a very small number of large ReS
2
particles might be involved because the area of the electrode was as large as 1 mm
2
. These large particles are not harmful to the photoactivation because the photoresponsivity of ReS
2
is not dependent on the thickness of nanosheets, unlike in other 2D TMDs (MoS
2
, MoSe
2
, WS
2
etc.). However, large nanosheets exceeding several tens of nanometers in thickness might have induced nonuniform turn-on behaviors in the WORM devices. In the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film, a highly localized electric field could be developed through the region where a large ReS
2
nanosheet was present and form a pathway for carrier transport between the top and bottom electrodes. Therefore, early electrical turn-on at a wide range of applied voltages might occur in the sample with no Al
2
O
3
layer. In contrast, in the case of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite with the Al
2
O
3
layer that could sustain the majority of the electric field, the uniformity of turn-on voltage was greatly improved. In the sample with an Al
2
O
3
layer, the turn-on occurred at near 5 V, which is lower than the breakdown voltages of very uniform Al
2
O
3
or Al
2
O
3
-PVA multilayers with no ReS
2
nanosheets (See
Figure S11
). The reason can be explained by a focused electrical field on a very small area confined by a large ReS
2
nanosheet unlike uniform field on a large-area of uniform Al
2
O
3
film, as compared in
Figure S12b,c
, respectively.
Figure
3
b,c shows the
I–V
characteristics of the transparent two-terminal devices with the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite. The devices on the glass and the large flexible substrates show very similar
I–V
behavior. Initially, when a positive voltage is applied, the device shows an HRS with a gradually increasing current (stage 1) with increasing voltage until the threshold voltage of 2.0 V is reached.
Figure
3
b shows that the current abruptly increases from 7.9 × 10
–7
to 2.8 × 10
–4
A at the threshold voltage; the device is in a low resistive state (LRS) at voltages exceeding 2.0 V. The device remains in the LRS during positive (stage 2) and reverse sweeps (stage 3) without current resetting by applying a voltage in the −5 to 5 V range (stages 4, 5, and 6).
Figure
3
d shows the stability of the LRS (1.0 × 10
–4
A) and HRS (1.0 × 10
–8
A) over 600 s, as well as the high ON/OFF current ratio of 1.0 × 10
4
at 0.5 V. These results demonstrate that the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite-based device shows WORM characteristics with high stability and a high ON/OFF ratio. The high ON/OFF current ratio of 10
4
obtained in this work is significantly higher than that of polymer–MoS
2
nanocomposite devices.
(4,33−35)
To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a memory device that uses a polymer–ReS
2
nanocomposite.

To examine the charge transport and conduction mechanisms of the WORM device, the
I–V
curves were fitted using three different carrier transport models: thermionic emission current, the SCLC model, and the Ohmic conduction model, as shown in
Figure
3
e,f. In the HRS state in the 0–0.1 V voltage regime, the plot of ln(
I
) vs
V
1/2
is well fitted to the straight line describing the thermionic emission process, as shown in the inset of
Figure
3
e.
(36)
In this state, electron injection mainly occurs between the GZO electrode and the ReS
2
–PVA active layer. From 0.1 to 2 V, the slope of the ln(
I
) vs ln(
V
) plot gradually increases from 1.17 to 3.65, as denoted in
Figure
3
e, which clarifies the contribution of the SCLC process to conduction in the device.
(37)
The charge is transferred from the PVA to the embedded ReS
2
nanosheets, gradually filling the shallow and deep trap sites of ReS
2
at a slope of 1.17 and the 2.66–3.65 slope region, respectively.
(38,39)
Most deep trap sites were caused by sulfur vacancies at the edge of the ReS
2
nanosheet. The electrons from deeper trap sites contribute to conduction at the higher slope. All trap sites are fully occupied by charges in the ON state, and the ln(
I
)–ln(
V
) region shows a slope of 1.13, as fitted by the Ohmic conduction model in
Figure
3
f.
(40)
The LRS is retained even when a reverse voltage is applied, which implies that charges trapped in deep-level sites in the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite film are not released at the reverse voltage of −5 V.

To further understand the resistive switching characteristics of the ReS
2
–PVA devices, the
I–V
curve of the Al
2
O
3
layer was acquired. The breakdown voltage was observed to increase with thickness, as shown in
Figure S11c
. The breakdown voltages of the 30 nm thick Al
2
O
3
layer and the device with the Al
2
O
3
layer were 21 and 2 V, respectively. Furthermore, the
I–V
curve of a device with only the PVA film was examined to determine the role of the ReS
2
nanosheets within the ReS
2
–
PVA nanocomposite. As shown in
Figure S11d
, turn-on behavior was not observed and the HRS was maintained in the −5 to 5 V range. Therefore, the abrupt increase in current at 2 V is caused by the ReS
2
nanosheets in the device with the Al
2
O
3
layer. These results indicate that conductive filaments were formed by localized high electric fields at the ReS
2
nanosheet edges involving sulfur vacancies;
(34)
these sulfur vacancies act as shallow and deep trap sites. When a reverse voltage is applied, conductive filaments with trapped charges cannot be detrapped. Therefore, the device shows WORM memory behavior.

Figure
4
a shows the structure of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor under light irradiation. The conceptual diagram depicts two adjacent neurons with synapses where an appropriate photonic stimulus is applied to the presynaptic neuron, and the photogenerated carriers move toward the postsynaptic neuron (receptor) to generate the EPSC. Because the 2D ReS
2
nanosheet is photoresponsive irrespective of thickness, we examined the photoresponses of the ReS
2
–PVA memristors and studied their photosynaptic plasticities that might be governed by the deep trap sites. Such deep trap sites are expected to benefit synaptic plasticity phenomena such as LTP and LTM.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Schematic of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor and the conceptual diagram for two adjacent neurons with a synapse. (b)
I–V
characteristics in the dark and under illumination at 365, 400, and 455 nm. (c) Typical excitatory postsynaptic currents (EPSCs) of memristive synapse triggered by photonic stimulation under illumination for 15, 30, 60, and 120 s. (d) PPF index A2/A1 as a function of interval time (Δ
t
). The inset of
Figure
4
d shows the EPSC triggered by consecutive photonic pulses. The EPSC behavior is triggered by (e) pulse widths (PWs) of 7.5, 15, and 30 s at
V
ds
= 1 V. (f) Changes in EPSC by photonic excitation and negative electric modulation.

div.div:
First, we measured the photoresponsivity of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor in the SCLC region (HRS, −2 V <
V
ds
< 2 V) using light sources with wavelengths of 365, 400, and 455 nm, as shown in
Figure
4
b. While light irradiation at 400 and 455 nm generated little photocurrent, light irradiation at 365 nm increased the current at 2 V significantly, from 0.34 μA (dark) to 1.1 μA. To explain this increase, the absorbance of the ReS
2
–PVA film was measured. The small increase in photocurrent when irradiated at 400 and 455 nm is ascribed to the high absorbance of PVA at 400–600 nm.
Figure S13
shows light loss owing to PVA at wavelengths above 400 nm; the portion of light absorbed by the ReS
2
nanosheets increased greatly at 365 nm.
Figure
4
b also shows that the generated photocurrent is symmetric for positive and negative electric fields. Then, the device was operated to emulate synaptic plasticity using the 365 nm light source.
Figure
4
c–e shows the results of synaptic measurements for the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor; typical EPSC characteristics were observed under photonic stimulation at
V
ds
= 1 V (HRS). The EPSC increased from 0.14 to 0.18 μA (an increase of 28.6%), 0.22 μA (an increase of 57.1%), 0.24 μA (an increase of 71.4%), and 0.26 μA (an increase of 85.7%) when irradiated for 15, 30, 60, and 120 s, respectively, as shown in
Figure
4
c. The current slowly decreases with time when the light is turned off. To compare the carrier detrapping behavior after the light is turned off, the relaxation time (τ) was calculated using a modified Kohlrausch equation:
(41)
(1)
where
I
0
is the current in the stabilized state and
A
is a prefactor. The extracted τ values from the decay curves after irradiation for 15, 30, 60, and 120 s are 416.4, 283.0, 276.9, and 230.2 s, respectively, as shown in
Figure S14
, which implies that more electrons are produced during long-term irradiation; a limited number of electrons were trapped in deep trap sites, while the other electrons were trapped in shallow trap sites. The electrons in the shallow trap sites were more easily released over 1000 s. Therefore, the shallow trap sites have a small τ on account of easy trapping and release. Normally, a higher photocurrent level decreases more significantly over time. Thus, a longer irradiation time corresponds to a smaller τ. Moreover, this result demonstrates that these devices have longer memories than earlier synaptic memory devices with polymer–2D TMDs or conducting polymers. The previously reported τ values of synaptic memory devices were in the 10–2000 ms
(42)
or 10–100 s range.
(41,43,44)
The dependence of the PPF index (A2/A1, the intensity ratio of the peaks shown in the inset of
Figure
4
d) on the time interval (Δ
t
) between two consecutive photonic pulses is plotted in
Figure
4
d. The PPF index value is 178.1% at an interval of 5 s and a fixed PW of 5 s, as shown in the inset of
Figure
4
d; further, the PPF index values gradually decrease as the interval (Δ
t
) increases. The decrease of PPF with Δ
t
may be due to the detrapping and dissipation of more carriers during the longer Δ
t
.

We also emulated excitatory synaptic behavior with respect to PW and PN at Δ
t
= 100 s and
V
ds
= 1 V. The EPSC gradually enhances with increasing PW because of the increase of the number of photogenerated carriers, as shown in
Figure
4
e. The EPSC level can be increased further if the experiment is performed at Δ
t
< 100 s. The EPSC increases with increasing PN at a fixed PW of 30 s and a Δ
t
of 100 s, as shown in
Figure S15
. These results indicate that short-term memory can be transferred to LTM through repetitive stimulation by increasing the PW and PN. In previous work based on photosensitive synaptic behavior of a stand-alone MoS
2
nanoflake, the time scale was on the 10 ms level.
(45)
However, the time scale of ReS
2
embedded in PVA shown in this work was limited by the polymer matrix. We believe that the photosensitivity and response time can be further improved by modifying the ReS
2
-PVA nanocomposite films in future works.

Inhibitory synaptic behavior is also emulated using negative electric stimuli, as shown in
Figure
4
f. Because this measurement region is in the HRS (<2 V), electrons can be released, unlike in the LRS (following WORM memory behavior). The EPSC arising from photostimulation for 120 s gradually decreases under repeated electrical pulses with −3 V (PW = 5 s) at
V
ds
= 1 V. The
τ
of synaptic memory was 127.7 s, as shown in
Figure S16
, which is very short compared to that observed with 120 s of irradiation (τ = 230.2 s;
Figure
4
c). This result shows that the electrons in deep trap sites can be released by negative electric stimuli at −3 V and that excitatory and inhibitory synaptic behavior can be mimicked by photonic and electric modulation, respectively.

The physical mechanism for the synaptic behavior of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor can be discussed based on the diagram in
Figure
5
. The memory behavior discussed above can be explained by charge trapping and release by the ReS
2
nanosheets in the PVA matrix. The work function of GZO is −4.4 eV,
(46)
and the highest occupied molecular orbital and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of PVA are −6.69 and – 3.43 eV, respectively.
(47)
The electron affinity and band gap of ReS
2
are −4.68 and 1.5 eV, respectively, as shown in
Figure
5
.
(48)
A large number of electrons generated in the ReS
2
nanosheets by photonic stimulus are captured in the shallow- and deep-level trap sites in the ReS
2
nanosheets, as shown in
Figure
5
a. After cessation of photonic stimulation, the electrons in the shallow trap sites are easily released and dissipated. However, electrons in the deep trap sites are released very slowly, as shown in
Figure
5
b. Therefore, the LTM behavior must arise from the electrons captured in the deep-level trap sites, which mostly exist at the edges of the 2D single-crystalline ReS
2
nanosheets.
(49,50)

div.p:
Figure 5. Energy band diagram of the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor with (a) light on and (b) light off.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We successfully exfoliated ReS
2
nanosheets in an aqueous PVA solution without adding surfactants or ions that must be removed before device fabrication. Then, flexible transparent memristors with a ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite were fabricated on glass and polyimide substrates using this simple, cost-effective PVA-assisted exfoliation method. This surfactant-free method showed high exfoliation efficiency and yielded stable ReS
2
suspensions suitable for the fabrication of electronic devices directly on substrates without additional cleaning processes. A transparent memristor with the GZO/Al
2
O
3
/ReS
2
–PVA/GZO/substrate configuration showed WORM memory behavior with a high ON/OFF current ratio of 1.0 × 10.
(4)
The conduction mechanism of the device in the HRS state is explained well using the SCLC model. In addition, the ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite memristor mimicked both excitatory and inhibitory synaptic plasticity behavior, such as EPSC, PPF, LTP, LTD, and LTM. The long relaxation time and LTM behavior imply that the synaptic behavior arises from deep trap sites in the ReS
2
nanosheets. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a ReS
2
–PVA nanocomposite photosynaptic memristor. The fabrication of other 2D TMD–polymer nanocomposite synaptic devices using the strategy suggested in this work may facilitate the development of simple and inexpensive devices using LPE 2D nanosheets.

I–V

Exfoliated MoS2 Nanocomposite as an Anode Material for Lithium Ion Batteries
Xiao, Jie; Choi, Daiwon; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Koech, Phillip; Liu, Jun; Lemmon, John P.

Conventional Li-ion batteries utilize graphite as the anode materials. The low theor. capacity of graphite (372 mA h/g) makes it important to find alternative neg. electrodes. Si (4200 mA h/g) or Sn (994 mA h/g) attract much interest because of their high capacity. The application of Si or Sn anodes in lithium ion batteries was limited by their poor cycling characteristic caused by large vol. changes which occur during the repeated alloying and dealloying process with lithium. However, the electrochem. properties of the as-prepd. materials were not investigated. Nanocomposites may provide improved performance by inserting the lithium ion coordination properties of PEO into the interlayer spacing of MoS2 allowing for increased ion transfer. This property along with the reported increase of capacity in restacked MoS2 has led us to revisit this material as an anode for Li-ion batteries. The morphologies of the original lithiated MoS2, exfoliated MoS2 and PEO/MoS2 composite are compared.

Enhanced Hydrogen Evolution Catalysis from Chemically Exfoliated Metallic MoS2 Nanosheets
Lukowski, Mark A.; Daniel, Andrew S.; Meng, Fei; Forticaux, Audrey; Li, Linsen; Jin, Song

Promising catalytic activity from MoS2 in the H evolution reaction (HER) is attributed to active sites located along the edges of its 2-dimensional layered crystal structure, but its performance is limited by the d. and reactivity of active sites, poor elec. transport, and inefficient elec. contact to the catalyst. Here the authors report enhanced HER catalysis (an electrocatalytic c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 at a low overpotential of -187 mV vs. RHE and a Tafel slope of 43 mV/decade) from metallic nanosheets of 1T-MoS2 chem. exfoliated via Li intercalation from semiconducting 2H-MoS2 nanostructures grown directly on graphite. Structural characterization and electrochem. studies confirmed that the nanosheets of the metallic MoS2 polymorph exhibit facile electrode kinetics and low-loss elec. transport and possess a proliferated d. of catalytic active sites. These distinct and previously unexploited features of 1T-MoS2 make these metallic nanosheets a highly competitive earth-abundant HER catalyst.

He, Qiyuan; Zeng, Zhiyuan; Yin, Zongyou; Li, Hai; Wu, Shixin; Huang, Xiao; Zhang, Hua

By combining two kinds of soln.-processable two-dimensional materials, a flexible transistor array is fabricated in which MoS2 thin film is used as the active channel and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) film is used as the drain and source electrodes. The simple device configuration and the 1.5 mm-long MoS2 channel ensure highly reproducible device fabrication and operation. This flexible transistor array can be used as a highly sensitive gas sensor with excellent reproducibility. Compared to using rGO thin film as the active channel, this new gas sensor exhibits much higher sensitivity. Moreover, functionalization of the MoS2 thin film with Pt nanoparticles further increases the sensitivity by up to ∼3 times. The successful incorporation of a MoS2 thin-film into the electronic sensor promises its potential application in various electronic devices.

A facile method for exfoliation and dispersion of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) with the aid of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) is proposed. The resultant PVP-coated MoS2 nanosheets, i.e., MoS2-PVP nanocomposites, are well dispersed in the low-boiling ethanol solvent, facilitating their thin film prepn. and the device fabrication by soln. processing technique. As a proof of concept, a flexible memory diode with the configuration of reduced graphene oxide (rGO)/MoS2-PVP/Al exhibited a typical bistable elec. switching and nonvolatile rewritable memory effect with the function of flash. The elec. transition is due to the charge trapping and detrapping behavior of MoS2 in the PVP dielec. material. This study paves a way of employing two-dimensional nanomaterials as both functional materials and conducting electrodes for the future flexible data storage.

Neural population dynamics during reaching
Churchland, Mark M.; Cunningham, John P.; Kaufman, Matthew T.; Foster, Justin D.; Nuyujukian, Paul; Ryu, Stephen I.; Shenoy, Krishna V.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(
2012
),

(

; ISSN:
0028-0836
.

Nature Publishing Group
)
Most theories of motor cortex have assumed that neural activity represents movement parameters. This view derives from what is known about primary visual cortex, where neural activity represents patterns of light. Yet it is unclear how well the analogy between motor and visual cortex holds. Single-neuron responses in motor cortex are complex, and there is marked disagreement regarding which movement parameters are represented. A better analogy might be with other motor systems, where a common principle is rhythmic neural activity. Here we find that motor cortex responses during reaching contain a brief but strong oscillatory component, something quite unexpected for a non-periodic behavior. Oscillation amplitude and phase followed naturally from the preparatory state, suggesting a mechanistic role for preparatory neural activity. These results demonstrate an unexpected yet surprisingly simple structure in the population response. This underlying structure explains many of the confusing features of individual neural responses.

Fast kinetics of magnesium monochloride cations in interlayer-expanded titanium disulfide for magnesium rechargeable batteries
Yoo, Hyun Deog; Liang, Yanliang; Dong, Hui; Lin, Junhao; Wang, Hua; Liu, Yisheng; Ma, Lu; Wu, Tianpin; Li, Yifei; Ru, Qiang; Jing, Yan; An, Qinyou; Zhou, Wu; Guo, Jinghua; Lu, Jun; Pantelides, Sokrates T.; Qian, Xiaofeng; Yao, Yan

Magnesium rechargeable batteries potentially offer high-energy d., safety, and low cost due to the ability to employ divalent, dendrite-free, and earth-abundant magnesium metal anode. Despite recent progress, further development remains stagnated mainly due to the sluggish scission of magnesium-chloride bond and slow diffusion of divalent magnesium cations in cathodes. Here we report a battery chem. that utilizes magnesium monochloride cations in expanded titanium disulfide. Combined theor. modeling, spectroscopic anal., and electrochem. study reveal fast diffusion kinetics of magnesium monochloride cations without scission of magnesium-chloride bond. The battery demonstrates the reversible intercalation of 1 and 1.7 magnesium monochloride cations per titanium at 25 and 60°C, resp., corresponding to up to 400 mAh g-1 capacity based on the mass of titanium disulfide. The large capacity accompanies with excellent rate and cycling performances even at room temp., opening up possibilities for a variety of effective intercalation hosts for multivalent-ion batteries.

A VLSI recurrent network of integrate-and-fire neurons connected by plastic synapses with long-term memory
Chicca E; Badoni D; Dante V; D'Andreagiovanni M; Salina G; Carota L; Fusi S; Del Giudice P
IEEE transactions on neural networks
(
2003
),
14
(
5
),
1297-307
ISSN:
1045-9227
.
Electronic neuromorphic devices with on-chip, on-line learning should be able to modify quickly the synaptic couplings to acquire information about new patterns to be stored (synaptic plasticity) and, at the same time, preserve this information on very long time scales (synaptic stability). Here, we illustrate the electronic implementation of a simple solution to this stability-plasticity problem, recently proposed and studied in various contexts. It is based on the observation that reducing the analog depth of the synapses to the extreme (bistable synapses) does not necessarily disrupt the performance of the device as an associative memory, provided that 1) the number of neurons is large enough; 2) the transitions between stable synaptic states are stochastic; and 3) learning is slow. The drastic reduction of the analog depth of the synaptic variable also makes this solution appealing from the point of view of electronic implementation and offers a simple methodological alternative to the technological solution based on floating gates. We describe the full custom analog very large-scale integration (VLSI) realization of a small network of integrate-and-fire neurons connected by bistable deterministic plastic synapses which can implement the idea of stochastic learning. In the absence of stimuli, the memory is preserved indefinitely. During the stimulation the synapse undergoes quick temporary changes through the activities of the pre- and postsynaptic neurons; those changes stochastically result in a long-term modification of the synaptic efficacy. The intentionally disordered pattern of connectivity allows the system to generate a randomness suited to drive the stochastic selection mechanism. We check by a suitable stimulation protocol that the stochastic synaptic plasticity produces the expected pattern of potentiation and depression in the electronic network.

Indiveri Giacomo; Chicca Elisabetta; Douglas Rodney

We present a mixed-mode analog/digital VLSI device comprising an array of leaky integrate-and-fire (I&F) neurons, adaptive synapses with spike-timing dependent plasticity, and an asynchronous event based communication infrastructure that allows the user to (re)configure networks of spiking neurons with arbitrary topologies. The asynchronous communication protocol used by the silicon neurons to transmit spikes (events) off-chip and the silicon synapses to receive spikes from the outside is based on the "address-event representation" (AER). We describe the analog circuits designed to implement the silicon neurons and synapses and present experimental data showing the neuron's response properties and the synapses characteristics, in response to AER input spike trains. Our results indicate that these circuits can be used in massively parallel VLSI networks of I&F neurons to simulate real-time complex spike-based learning algorithms.

A review. Although great progress was achieved in the study of graphene, the small current ON/OFF ratio in graphene-based field-effect transistors (FETs) limits its application in the fields of conventional transistors or logic circuits for low-power electronic switching. Recently, layered transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) materials, esp. MoS2, have attracted increasing attention. In contrast to its bulk material with an indirect band gap, a single-layer (1L) MoS2 nanosheet is a semiconductor with a direct band gap of ∼1.8 eV, which makes it a promising candidate for optoelectronic applications due to the enhancement of photoluminescence and high current ON/OFF ratio. Compared with TMD nanosheets prepd. by CVD and liq. exfoliation, mech. exfoliated ones possess pristine, clean, and high-quality structures, which are suitable for the fundamental study and potential applications based on their intrinsic thickness-dependent properties. In this Account, the authors summarize the authors' recent research on the prepn., characterization, and applications of 1L and multilayer MoS2 and WSe2 nanosheets produced by mech. exfoliation. During the prepn. of nanosheets, the authors proposed a simple optical identification method to distinguish 1L and multilayer MoS2 and WSe2 nanosheets on a Si substrate coated with 90 and 300 nm SiO2. Raman spectroscopy was used to characterize mech. exfoliated 1L and multilayer WSe2 nanosheets. For the 1st time, a new Raman peak at 308 cm-1 was obsd. in the spectra of WSe2 nanosheets except for the 1L WSe2 nanosheet. Importantly, the 1L WSe2 nanosheet is very sensitive to the laser power during characterization. The high power laser-induced local oxidn. of WSe2 nanosheets and single crystals was monitored by Raman spectroscopy and at. force microscopy (AFM). Hexagonal and monoclinic structured WO3 thin films were obtained from the local oxidization of single- to triple-layer (1L-3L) and quadruple- to quintuple-layer (4L-5L) WSe2 nanosheets, resp. Then, the Raman characterization of shear and breathing modes of 1L and multilayer MoS2 and WSe2 nanosheets in the low frequency range (<50 cm-1), which can be used to accurately identify the layer no. of nanosheets. Magnetic force microscopy was used to characterize 1L and multilayer MoS2 nanosheets, and thickness-dependent magnetic response was found. In the last part, the authors briefly introduce the applications of 1L and multilayer MoS2 nanosheets in the fields of gas sensors and phototransistors.

The rise of 2D transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) materials has enormous implications for the scientific community and beyond. Among TMDs, ReX2 (X = S, Se) has attracted significant interest regarding its unusual 1T' structure and extraordinary properties in various fields during the past 7 years. For instance, ReX2 possesses large bandgaps (ReSe2: 1.3 eV, ReS2: 1.6 eV), distinctive interlayer decoupling, and strong anisotropic properties, which endow more degree of freedom for constructing novel optoelectronic, logic circuit, and sensor devices. Moreover, facile ion intercalation, abundant active sites, together with stable 1T' structure enable them great perspective to fabricate high-performance catalysts and advanced energy storage devices. In this review, the structural features, fundamental physicochem. properties, as well as all existing applications of Re-based TMDs materials are comprehensively introduced. Esp., the emerging synthesis strategies are critically analyzed and pay particular attention is paid to its growth mechanism with probing the assembly process of domain architectures. Finally, current challenges and future opportunities regarding the controlled prepn. methods, property, and application exploration of Re-based TMDs are discussed.

Donarelli, M.; Prezioso, S.; Perrozzi, F.; Bisti, F.; Nardone, M.; Giancaterini, L.; Cantalini, C.; Ottaviano, L.

We report on the fabrication, the morphol., structural, and chem. characterization, and the study of the elec. response to NO2 and other gases of resistive type gas sensors based on liq. chem. exfoliated (in N-Me pyrrolidone, NMP) MoS2 flakes annealed in air either at 150° or at 250°. The active material has been analyzed by SEM, and micro Raman and X-ray core level photoemission spectroscopies. SEM shows that MoS2 exfoliated flakes are interconnected between electrodes of the sensing device to form percolation paths. Raman spectroscopy of the flakes before annealing demonstrates that the flakes are constituted by cryst. MoS2, while, annealing at 250°, does not introduce a detectable bulk contamination in the expected form of MoO3. The sensor obtained by thermal annealing in air at 150° exhibits a peculiar p-type response under exposure to NO2. In line with core level spectroscopy evidences, this behavior is potentially ascribed to nitrogen substitutional doping of S vacancies in the MoS2 surface (nitrogen atoms being likely provided by the intercalated NMP). Thermal annealing the MoS2 flakes in air at 250° irreversibly sets an n-type behavior of the gas sensing device, with a NO2 detection limit of 20 ppb. This behavior is assigned, in line with core level spectroscopy data, to a significant presence of S vacancies in the MoS2 annealed flakes and to the surface co-existence of MoO3 arising from the partial oxidn. of the flakes surface. Both p- and n-type sensors have been demonstrated to be sensitive also to relative humidity. The n-type sensor shows good elec. response under H2 exposure.

The authors have studied the dispersion and exfoliation of four inorg. layered compds., WS2, MoS2, MoSe2, and MoTe2, in a range of org. solvents. The aim was to explore the relation between the chem. structure of the exfoliated nanosheets and their dispersibility. Sonication of the layered compds. in solvents generally gave few-layer nanosheets with lateral dimensions of a few hundred nanometers. However, the dispersed concn. varied greatly from solvent to solvent. For all four materials, the concn. peaked for solvents with surface energy close to 70 mJ/m2, implying that all four have surface energy close to this value. Inverse gas chromatog. measurements showed MoS2 and MoSe2 to have surface energies of ∼75 mJ/m2, in good agreement with dispersibility measurements. However, this method suggested MoTe2 to have a considerably larger surface energy (∼120 mJ/m2). While surface-energy-based soly. parameters are perhaps more intuitive for two-dimensional materials, Hansen soly. parameters are probably more useful. The anal. shows the dispersed concn. of all four layered materials to show well-defined peaks when plotted as a function of Hansen's dispersive, polar, and H-bonding soly. parameters. Probably the authors can assoc. Hansen soly. parameters of δD ∼ 18 MPa1/2, δP ∼ 8.5 MPa1/2, and δH ∼ 7 MPa1/2 with all four types of layered material. Knowledge of these properties allows the estn. of the Flory-Huggins parameter, χ, for each combination of nanosheet and solvent. The dispersed concn. of each material falls exponentially with χ as predicted by soln. thermodn. Soln. thermodn. and specifically soly. parameter anal. can be used as a framework to understand the dispersion of two-dimensional materials. Finally, in good solvents, such as cyclohexylpyrrolidone, the dispersions are temporally stable with >90% of material remaining dispersed after 100 h.

The search for high-capacity, low-cost electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries is a significant challenge in energy research. Among the many potential candidates, layered compds. such as MoS2 have attracted increasing attention. However, such materials have not yet fulfilled their true potential. Here, we show that networks of liq. phase exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets, reinforced with 20 wt % single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWNTs), can be formed into sodium-ion battery electrodes with large gravimetric, volumetric, and areal capacity. The MoS2/SWNT composite films are highly porous, elec. conductive, and mech. robust due to its percolating carbon nanotube network. When directly employed as the working electrode, they exhibit a specific capacity of >400 mAh/g and volumetric capacity of ∼650 mAh/cm3. Their mech. stability allows them to be processed into free-standing films with tunable thickness up to ∼100 μm, corresponding to an areal loading of 15 mg/cm2. Their high elec. cond. allows the high volumetric capacity to be retained, even at high thickness, resulting in state-of-the-art areal capacities of >4.0 mAh/cm2. Such values are competitive with their lithium-ion counterparts.

Atomically thin 2D layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been extensively studied in recent years because of their appealing elec. and optical properties. Here, the fabrication of ReS2 field-effect transistors is reported via the encapsulation of ReS2 nanosheets in a high-κ Al2O3 dielec. environment. Low-temp. transport measurements allow to observe a direct metal-to-insulator transition originating from strong electron-electron interactions. Remarkably, the photodetectors based on ReS2 exhibit gate-tunable photo response up to 16.14 A W-1 and external quantum efficiency reaching 3168%, showing a competitive device performance to those reported in graphene, MoSe2, GaS, and GaSe-based photodetectors. This study unambiguously distinguishes ReS2 as a new candidate for future applications in electronics and optoelectronics.

2D transition metal dichalcogenides are emerging with tremendous potential in many optoelectronic applications due to their strong light-matter interactions. To fully explore their potential in photoconductive detectors, high responsivity is required. Here, high responsivity phototransistors based on few-layer Re disulfide (ReS2) are presented. Depending on the back gate voltage, source drain bias and incident optical light intensity, the max. attainable photoresponsivity can reach ≤88,600 A W-1, which is a record value compared to other individual 2-dimensional materials with similar device structures and 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of monolayer MoS2. Such high photoresponsivity is attributed to the increased light absorption as well as the gain enhancement due to the existence of trap states in the few-layer ReS2 flakes. It further enables the detection of weak signals, as successfully demonstrated with weak light sources including a lighter and limited fluorescent lighting. The studies underscore ReS2 as a promising material for future sensitive optoelectronic applications.

Thermally Driven Crossover from Indirect toward Direct Bandgap in 2D Semiconductors: MoSe2 versus MoS2
Tongay, Sefaattin; Zhou, Jian; Ataca, Can; Lo, Kelvin; Matthews, Tyler S.; Li, Jingbo; Grossman, Jeffrey C.; Wu, Junqiao
Nano Letters

American Chemical Society

Layered semiconductors based on transition-metal chalcogenides usually cross from indirect bandgap in the bulk limit over to direct bandgap in the quantum (2D) limit. Such a crossover can be achieved by peeling off a multilayer sample to a single layer. For exploration of phys. behavior and device applications, it is much desired to reversibly modulate such crossover in a multilayer sample. In a few-layer sample where the indirect bandgap and direct bandgap are nearly degenerate, the temp. rise can effectively drive the system toward the 2D limit by thermally decoupling neighboring layers via interlayer thermal expansion. Such a situation is realized in few-layer MoSe2, which shows Stark contrast from the well-explored MoS2 where the indirect and direct bandgaps are far from degenerate. Luminescence of few-layer MoSe2 is much enhanced with the temp. rise, much like the way that the luminescence is enhanced due to the bandgap crossover going from the bulk to the quantum limit, offering potential applications involving external modulation of optical properties in 2D semiconductors. The direct bandgap of MoSe2, identified at 1.55 eV, may also promise applications in energy conversion involving solar spectrum, as it is close to the optimal bandgap value of single-junction solar cells and photoelectrochem. devices.

It has been well-established that single layer MX2 (M = Mo, W and X = S, Se) are direct gap semiconductors with band edges coinciding at the K point in contrast to their indirect gap multilayer counterparts. In few-layer MX2, there are two valleys along the Γ-K line with similar energy. There is little understanding on which of the two valleys forms the conduction band min. (CBM) in this thickness regime. We investigate the conduction band valley structure in few-layer MX2 by examg. the temp.-dependent shift of indirect exciton photoluminescence peak. Highly anisotropic thermal expansion of the lattice and the corresponding evolution of the band structure result in a distinct peak shift for indirect transitions involving the K and Λ (midpoint along Γ-K) valleys. We identify the origin of the indirect emission and concurrently det. the relative energy of these valleys.

Novel phys. phenomena can emerge in low-dimensional nanomaterials. Bulk MoS2, a prototypical metal dichalcogenide, is an indirect bandgap semiconductor with negligible photoluminescence. When the MoS2 crystal is thinned to monolayer, however, a strong photoluminescence emerges, indicating an indirect to direct bandgap transition in this d-electron system. Quantum confinement in layered d-electron materials like MoS2 provides new opportunities for engineering the electronic structure of matter at the nanoscale.

ReS2 films with different thickness are fabricated by a vacuum filtration from liq. exfoliated ReS2 suspension. The saturable absorption properties of these films are investigated by an open-aperture Z-scan technique with a femtosecond laser. The saturable absorption coeffs. αNL and the imaginary part of the third-order optical susceptibility Imχ(3) are from -61.5 to -171.8 cm/GW and from -2.24 × 10-11 to -6.27 × 10-11 esu with the change of thickness. The figure of merit increases with the increasing of the thickness of ReS2 films, which suggests the possible layer-coupling influence to the nonlinear optical properties. A double-covered ReS2 microfiber as a saturable absorber is then fabricated. We obtain stable mode-locking pulses with highdamage threshold (410 mW), which are centered at 1563.3 nm with the duration of 3.8 ps and the fundamental repetition of 1.78 MHz. Our results provide complementary information for the reliable ReS2 film fabrication with good nonlinear optical property for the mode-locking fiber lasers.

Environmentally friendly synthesis and scalable photoelectrode fabrication are important for the photoelec. conversion in photocurrent generation. We find that 28% ethanol in 72% deionized water are the best mixed solvent for efficient exfoliation of layered ReS2 by absorption spectra and the enthalpy of mixing theory. Electrophoretic deposition method is used to fabricate photoelectrodes with different thicknesses by controlling the deposition time. These photoelectrodes demonstrate fast and stable photoelec. response and enhanced photocurrent with the thickness of the nanosheet films controlled by the deposition time. We also discuss the photoelec. mechanism as well as the influence of the effective mass of the monolayer, two-layer, and bulk ReS2 via Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). This work paves the way for the solvent selection in exfoliation of ReS2 nanosheets as well as the scalable fabrications for the photodetectors, photoelectrodes, and other solar energy conversion devices.

The exfoliation of graphite was studied in aq. solns. contg. Na dodecyl sulfate (SDS) as a surfactant. The exfoliation was greatly enhanced near the surface aggregation concn. (SAC) of SDS, 2.6 mM, and then decreased for higher SDS contents. However, the flakes exfoliated near the SAC were graphite, whereas graphene was obtained above the crit. micelle concn. (CMC). The effect of the use of alcs. as surface-tension-reducing agents (STRAs) on the exfoliation was then studied. With Et alc., a dispersion of 2.1 mg ml-1 graphene was achieved from 2.6 mM SDS after only 1 h of sonication, whereas a dispersion of 0.2 mg ml-1 was obtained above the CMC in the absence of STRAs. The SDS content near the SAC is highly beneficial for exfoliation as long as the surface tension is maintained near 41.0 mN ml-1. This finding supports the notion that the structure of the adsorbed SDS, depending on its concn., strongly affects the exfoliation of graphite into graphene.

To explain the effectiveness of the unimers in the exfoliation, the influence of the micellar size of a biocompatible block copolymer, Pluronic F-68, is evaluated in view of the yield and thickness of exfoliated 2D flakes. The authors also suggested the dielectrophoresis technique as a method for forming a film composed of 2D flakes for diverse applications requiring elec. signals. The unimer-assisted exfoliation method will be substantially utilized to achieve highly concd. aq. dispersion solns. of 2D materials.

A review. Polyvinyl alc. (PVA) was created about 90 years ago as the first synthetic colloid and it has been used for various applications since then. One of the significant applications of PVA is in the building industry. It was found that PVA can be used as a modifier, aggregate surface pre-treatment agent and fiber reinforcement in cement-based composite materials. This paper provides a review on the phys. properties of PVA and discusses on the effects of PVA towards the engineering properties of cement-based composite materials. The effects of PVA on the changes in the fracture surface, structure of the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) and compn. in ITZ of cement-based composite materials are also presented. In addn., the needs in research for future development of PVA in the building industry are also addressed.

Efficient prepn. of single-layer 2-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides, esp. molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), offers readily available 2D surface in nanoscale to template various materials to form nanocomposites with van der Waals heterostructures (vdWHs), opening up a new dimension for the design of functional electronic and optoelectronic materials and devices. The authors report the tunable memory properties of the facilely prepd. [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM)-MoS2 nanocomposites in a conventional diode device structure, where the vdWHs dominate the elec. characteristics of the devices for various memory behaviors depending on different surface deposition ratios of PCBM on MoS2 nanosheets. Both nonvolatile WORM and flash memory devices have been realized using the new developed PCBM-MoS2 2D composites. Specially, the flash characteristic devices show rewritable resistive switching with low switching voltages (∼2 V), high current on/off ratios (∼3 × 102), and superior elec. bistability (>104 s). This research, through successfully allocating massive vdWHs on the MoS2 surface for org./inorg. 2D nanocomposites, illustrates the great potential of 2D vdWHs in rectifying the electronic properties for high-performance memory devices and paves a way for the design of promising 2D nanocomposites with electronically active vdWHs for advanced device applications.

Elec. bistability is demonstrated in a polymer memory device with an active layer consisting of conjugated poly(3-hexylthiophene) and Au nanoparticles capped with 1-dodecanethiol sandwiched between 2 metal electrodes. Above a threshold voltage the pristine device, which was in a low cond. state, exhibited an increase in cond. by more than three orders of magnitude. The device could be returned to the low cond. state by applying a voltage in the reverse direction. The electronic transition is attributed to an elec.-field-induced charge transfer between the 2 components in the system. The conduction mechanism changed from a charge-injection-controlled current in the low cond. state to a charge-transport-controlled current in the high cond. state. In the high cond. state the conduction was dominated by a field-enhanced thermal excitation of trapped charges at room temp., while it is dominated by charge tunneling at low temps. The device exhibited excellent stability in both the cond. states and could be cycled between the 2 states for numerous times. The device exhibits tremendous potential for its application as fast, stable, low-cost, high storage d. nonvolatile electronic memory.

Bulk MoS2, a prototypical layered transition-metal dichalcogenide, is an indirect band gap semiconductor. Reducing its slab thickness to a monolayer, MoS2 undergoes a transition to the direct band semiconductor. We support this exptl. observation by first-principle calcns. and show that quantum confinement in layered d-electron dichalcogenides results in tuning the electronic structure. We further studied the properties of related TS2 nanolayers (T= W, Nb, Re) and show that the isotopol. WS2 exhibits similar electronic properties, while NbS2 and ReS2 remain metallic independent of the slab thickness.

Low-frequency current fluctuations are investigated over a bias range covering Ohmic, trap-filling, and space-charge-limited current regimes in polycryst. polyacenes. The relative current noise power spectral d. S(f) is const. in the Ohmic region, steeply increases at the trap-filling transition region, and decreases in the space-charge-limited-current region. The noise peak at the trap-filling transition is accounted for within a continuum percolation model. As the quasi-Fermi level crosses the trap level, intricate insulating paths nucleate within the Ohmic matrix, detg. the onset of nonequil. conditions at the interface between the insulating and conducting phase. The noise peak is written in terms of the free and trapped charge carrier densities.

The effect of RuO2 electrodes and La2O3 resistive layer were analyzed on the elec. and ferroelec. properties of BiFeO3 (BFO) films deposited on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrates using a chem. soln. method. XRD patterns revealed that BFO films with RuO2 and La2O3 layers appeared preferred (0 1 2) orientation. The surfaces of the BFO films with the La2O3 layer appeared uniform with dense grain clusters. The utilization of La2O3 and RuO2 layers reduced the diffusion of Ti and Si into the BFO films. Leakage mechanism of the films found specific to applied elec. field. At lower applied elec. field space-charge-limited current found dominant and at an applied elec. field >80 kV/cm surface-limited conduction (Fowler-Nordheim type) found the dominant. The BFO films grown with La2O3 resistive layers also contained lower concns. of Fe2+, which resulted enhancement of dielec. const. (ε), remnant polarization and lower leakage current. Among the studied films RuO2/BFO/La2O3/BFO/RuO2/Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si exhibited the best with value of relative permittivity (ε r) 208.8, leakage current 5.503 × 10-6 kV/cm2, remnant polarization (2P r) 3.80 μC/cm2, and coercive field (2Ec) 78.22 kV/cm.

A memristor with the simple structure Ag/poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)/Ta was fabricated. Essential synaptic plasticity and learning behaviors were emulated using this memristor, including short-term plasticity, long-term plasticity, spike-timing-dependent plasticity and spike-rate-dependent plasticity. Important time consts. were extd. from these synaptic modifications, which are assocd. with brain learning and memory functions. The movement of the Ag interface upon the initiation of a redox reaction accounts for the resistive switching mechanism of the authors' memristor. The conducting path in the polymer layer and the elastic effect of the polymer matrix probably are considered in the memory and learning processes. Also, the energy band diagram of the authors' memristor was drawn after the cross-sectional TEM images were analyzed. A natural p-n junction in the PEDOT:PSS/Ta compd. was formed. This resulted in rectifying, high resistance and low power consumption. The authors' device structure may be considered a feasible prototype for integrating memristors into a large-scale neuromorphic circuit.

Memristors have been extensively studied for nonvolatile memory storage, neuromorphic computing, and logic applications. Particularly, synapse emulation is viewed as a key step to realizing neuromorphic computing, because the biol. synapse is the basic unit for learning and memory. In this study, a memristor with the simple structure of Ta/viologen diperchlorate [EV(ClO4)2]/terpyridyl-iron polymer (TPy-Fe)/ITO is fabricated to simulate the functions of the synapse. Essential synaptic plasticity and learning behaviors are emulated by using this memristor, such as spike-timing-dependent plasticity and spike-rate-dependent plasticity. It is demonstrated that the redox between a terpyridyl-iron polymer and viologen species leads to our memristor behavior. Furthermore, the learning behavior depending on different amplitudes of voltage pulses is investigated as well. These demonstrations help pave the way for building bioinspired neuromorphic systems based on memristors.

Ga-doped ZnO (GZO)-graded layer, facilitating electron extn. from electron transport layer, was integrated on the surface of transparent indium tin oxide (ITO) cathode by using graded sputtering technique to improve the performance of planar n-i-p perovskite solar cells (PSCs). The thickness of graded GZO layer was controlled to optimize GZO-indium tin oxide (ITO) combined electrode for planar n-i-p PSCs. At optimized graded thickness of 15 nm, the GZO-ITO combined electrode showed an optical transmittance of 95%, a resistivity of 2.3 × 10-4 Ω cm, a sheet resistance of 15.6 Ω/square, and work function of 4.23 eV, which is well matched with the 4.0-eV LUMO of [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester. Owing to enhanced extn. of electron by the graded GZO, the n-i-p PSC with GZO-ITO combined electrode showed higher power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 9.67% than the PCE (5.25%) of PSC with only ITO electrode without GZO-graded layer. In addn., the GZO integrated-ITO electrode acts as transparent electrode and electron extn. layer simultaneously due to graded mixing of the GZO at the surface region of ITO electrode.

The human memory system plays an indispensable role in oblivion, learning, and memorization. Implementing a memory system within electronic devices contributes an important step toward constructing a neuromorphic system that emulates advanced mental functions of the human brain. Given the complex time-tailoring requirement, integrating a human memory system into one system is a great challenge. Here, one van der Waals heterostructure with flexible time-tailoring ability is demonstrated, which can meet the high requirement of human memory system programming. By stacking volatile and nonvolatile function layers, all basic memory types, including sensory memory, short-term and long-term memory are integrated into the device and the transition between these memory types are flexible. Moreover, decision-making action and in situ result storage are also demonstrated. It is anticipated that the demonstrated time-tailoring system will support the model of a human memory system.

The rapid development of artificial intelligence technol. has led to the urge for artificial optoelectronic synapses with visual perception and memory capabilities. A new type of artificial optoelectronic synapse, namely a photoelec. memcapacitor, is proposed and demonstrated. This photoelec. memcapacitor, with a planar Au/La1.875Sr0.125NiO4/Au metal-semiconductor-metal structure, displays a complementary optical and elec. modulation of capacitance, which can be attributed to the charge trapping/detrapping-induced Schottky barrier variation. It further exhibits versatile synaptic functions, such as photonic potentiation/elec. depression, paired-pulse facilitation, short-/long-term memory, and "learning-experience" behavior. Moreover, the photoplasticity of the memcapacitor can be modulated by varying the frequency of applied AC voltage, thus enabling self-adaptive optical signal detection and mimicry of interest-modulated human visual memory. Therefore, it represents a new paradigm for artificial optoelectronic synapses and opens up opportunities for developing low-power humanoid optoelectronic devices.

Exfoliated MoS2 Nanocomposite as an Anode Material for Lithium Ion Batteries
Xiao, Jie; Choi, Daiwon; Cosimbescu, Lelia; Koech, Phillip; Liu, Jun; Lemmon, John P.

Conventional Li-ion batteries utilize graphite as the anode materials. The low theor. capacity of graphite (372 mA h/g) makes it important to find alternative neg. electrodes. Si (4200 mA h/g) or Sn (994 mA h/g) attract much interest because of their high capacity. The application of Si or Sn anodes in lithium ion batteries was limited by their poor cycling characteristic caused by large vol. changes which occur during the repeated alloying and dealloying process with lithium. However, the electrochem. properties of the as-prepd. materials were not investigated. Nanocomposites may provide improved performance by inserting the lithium ion coordination properties of PEO into the interlayer spacing of MoS2 allowing for increased ion transfer. This property along with the reported increase of capacity in restacked MoS2 has led us to revisit this material as an anode for Li-ion batteries. The morphologies of the original lithiated MoS2, exfoliated MoS2 and PEO/MoS2 composite are compared.

Promising catalytic activity from MoS2 in the H evolution reaction (HER) is attributed to active sites located along the edges of its 2-dimensional layered crystal structure, but its performance is limited by the d. and reactivity of active sites, poor elec. transport, and inefficient elec. contact to the catalyst. Here the authors report enhanced HER catalysis (an electrocatalytic c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 at a low overpotential of -187 mV vs. RHE and a Tafel slope of 43 mV/decade) from metallic nanosheets of 1T-MoS2 chem. exfoliated via Li intercalation from semiconducting 2H-MoS2 nanostructures grown directly on graphite. Structural characterization and electrochem. studies confirmed that the nanosheets of the metallic MoS2 polymorph exhibit facile electrode kinetics and low-loss elec. transport and possess a proliferated d. of catalytic active sites. These distinct and previously unexploited features of 1T-MoS2 make these metallic nanosheets a highly competitive earth-abundant HER catalyst.

By combining two kinds of soln.-processable two-dimensional materials, a flexible transistor array is fabricated in which MoS2 thin film is used as the active channel and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) film is used as the drain and source electrodes. The simple device configuration and the 1.5 mm-long MoS2 channel ensure highly reproducible device fabrication and operation. This flexible transistor array can be used as a highly sensitive gas sensor with excellent reproducibility. Compared to using rGO thin film as the active channel, this new gas sensor exhibits much higher sensitivity. Moreover, functionalization of the MoS2 thin film with Pt nanoparticles further increases the sensitivity by up to ∼3 times. The successful incorporation of a MoS2 thin-film into the electronic sensor promises its potential application in various electronic devices.

A facile method for exfoliation and dispersion of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) with the aid of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) is proposed. The resultant PVP-coated MoS2 nanosheets, i.e., MoS2-PVP nanocomposites, are well dispersed in the low-boiling ethanol solvent, facilitating their thin film prepn. and the device fabrication by soln. processing technique. As a proof of concept, a flexible memory diode with the configuration of reduced graphene oxide (rGO)/MoS2-PVP/Al exhibited a typical bistable elec. switching and nonvolatile rewritable memory effect with the function of flash. The elec. transition is due to the charge trapping and detrapping behavior of MoS2 in the PVP dielec. material. This study paves a way of employing two-dimensional nanomaterials as both functional materials and conducting electrodes for the future flexible data storage.

Neural population dynamics during reaching
